content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-347-10-B |Item_parent=Acute urine retention |Item_parent_short=Acute urine retention |Rank=B |Title=Knowing the respective indications for bladder catheterisation and suprapubic catheterisation |Description=None |Topic=Management |Contributors=Jonathan Olivier |Order=10}} Any acute retention of urine is a therapeutic emergency, requiring bladder drainage, either trans-urethral or suprapubic. The type of drainage chosen depends on the context and the weaning objectives. {| class="wikitable" | |'''Bladder catheterisation'''' |Suprapubic catheterisation |- |'''Advantages''' |Simple Slope drainage Allows the bladder to be washed (haematuria: decaillotage) |Clamping test possible (assessment of voiding recovery) Avoiding the risk of urethral malpractice |- |'''Disadvantages'''' |No clamping test possible Risk of false urethral routes |Non-decubitus drainage Does not allow bladder cleansing (haematuria) |- |'''Contraindications'''' |Urethral trauma Stenosis of the urethra Trauma to the pelvis |Bladder tumour (risk of tumour spreading) Anticoagulation (risk of bladder clotting) Diagnostic doubt (risk of intestinal damage) Cross-vascular bypass Presence of subumbilical scars (relative CI) |} CI : Contraindication

properties.question: What is the primary indication for bladder catheterisation?
properties.option_a: Acute urinary retention in a patient with a history of bladder cancer
properties.option_b: Acute urinary retention in a patient with a history of bladder surgery
properties.option_c: Acute urinary retention in a patient with a history of urinary tract infections
properties.option_d: Acute urinary retention in a patient with a history of kidney stones
